answers.author: Cory Fleming
answers.text:
I think it begins by taking a fresh look at your community.  Go to each of the major entry points into your community and assess its appearance.  Are they nicely landscaped and attractive or do they look a bit worn and overgrown?  How is the signage?  Fresh and easy to read or faded?  
Drive around town and look at your directional signage.  Is it easy to get from point A to point B?  Is there adequate signage for the major attractions in your town, be they baseball fields, historical sites, the city hall or major parks? 
Does the community have adequate information on its website and/or printed material that highlight amenities and services available?  Does the community open itself up and invite others in through community festivals and other public entertainment offerings?  
Do local businesses and/or the local government sponsor hospitality training for front-line employees?  Does the chamber of commerce organize joint promotional programs that encourage people to visit and shop in the community?
And finally, do the residents of your community like where they live?  If people feel good about where they live, they will be your best sales force for the community.

answers.author: Cheryl Hilvert
answers.text:
Hi Ray!  Cory provided certainly some good thoughts above and all managers should think if these things in their day to day work.  When I saw your question, I thought of Peter Block and some of his philosophy on community building.  Peter advocates welcoming people to a meeting with food--even just cookies and coffee--and allowing some networking time to occur.  We do that in our homes when invite people over.  Do any of us ever think about that for our local government meetings. . .especially those where we are really trying to engage the public?

answers.author: Rob Hines
answers.text:
Hospitality is important and should be part of engagement. Hospitality starts with being a good host and to host you need to have a venue to invite people to. All too often, meeting in public, while essential, can be inconvenient for members of the public. Also, the kinds of in-person meetings that take place follow conventions that are not familiar to many people such as those found in a council meeting.  
I'd like to suggest that hospitality starts with making it convenient for the public to participate and that the online environment is the perfect place to host a community conversation for members of the public.  
Open Town Hall (http://www.opentownhall.com) makes it easy for government agencies to host members of the public in a community conversation. The platform allows local governments to choose the topics that are important to the community; monitor comments to ensure civility; and provide information about the topic.  
Most critical, a good government host doesn't only provide a place for conversation but communicates in return. This is done by informing the citizen about the outcome of important local issues once a decision has been made. After all, how effective would it be to invite people to a birthday party without the person who was having the birthday attending? If you're going to invite people to engage in local government, the most hospitable thing you can do is to make them feel that they were part of the decision making process.

answers.text:
Also when we invite people into our homes, we attempt to introduce guests to one another. 4 items that we think about in our City... How do you offer a sincere invitation?... How do you welcome people into your space?... How do you connect people to one another... How do you involve people in the conversation? Hospitality is something we all practice. Seldom is it considered in the context of Government.
